newsitem.title: UK: EIB sets first structured euro Eurobond, in lire.
newsitem.headline: EIB sets first structured euro Eurobond, in lire.

text.p: The European Investment Bank on Tuesday launched the first structured Eurobond that can be redenominated into euros after EMU, joint lead manager Banca Nazionale del Lavoro said.

Dealers said the structure had been adopted to overcome tax problems for Italian investors if the lira deal had been issued with the same coupon as other EIB bond issues with which it will, ultimately, be fungible.
The 1.0 trillion lire deal due February 2007 will carry a 9.00 percent coupon until February 15, 1999 when it will step down to 5.75 percent.

The deal, on which Credito Italiano and Paribas were also joint leads, will be fungible with outstanding EIB issues in escudos ZWFU, French francs ZVCM, guilders ZTVE and marks ZWNQ, all with 5.75 percent coupons.

Giving the EIB lira deal a 5.75 percent coupon would have meant pricing the deal at a chunky discount to par, given the higher level of long-term Italian interest rates. This, in turn, would leave Italian investors with a taxable capital gain.

The lead managers said in a statement: "The differentiated coupon structure aims at pricing the issue not below par, thus ensuring equal fiscal treatment for Italian residents versus previous EIB tributary issues".
While the coupon step-down is unconditional, the deal cannot be redenominated until Italy adopts the euro.

The third stage of European economic and monetary union, including the introduction of the European Union's planned single currency, the euro, is prescribed by EU law to take place no later than January 1, 1999.
